Upon Mr. Corner's retirement, Mr. Hamilton Owens has become editor-in chief and
Mr. Ross Veazy, assistant editor. Mr. N. Williams Haynes, '12, has been promoted to

We print in this issue an article on Darwinism, by our Mr. Haynes. Such an article is
especially apropos at this time, coming as it does right after the centenary of the great. Mr.
Haynes article is not in any sense technical, but treats the matter in a style calculated to make
the dullest freshman understand what has heretofore been to most of us but a name.

The Class of 1910 has finally succeeded in getting together, and organizing. We
always felt rather sorrow for that class, whose members never knew whether they were juniors
or sophomores. Now, however, we are inclined to envy them. A glance at the ticket elected
shows that every man got an office. Were we but a member, honor might have been heaped
upon us as well.
Looking over the ticket we cannot fail to be impressed with the literary value of the
class. A poet is president, two other poets serve beneath him, and an orator sits at his right
hand. Look to your laurels, oh ye of 1909.

The doors leading from McCoy Hall to Monument street and Druid Hill avenue open
inwards. The law requires doors from all public halls to open outwards. This rule, we
understand, is technically obeyed by having the doors from the Assembly Hall into the
corridor open outwards. This is no matter for technicalities! There is surely danger in the
present system, even though that danger be small.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

DARWIN'S THEORY.
The year 1809 saw the birth of many great
men, and we in 1909 .have been celebrating
many important centenaries. England honors
Fitzgerald, Gladstone and Tennyson; Germany, Mendelssohn, and in this country the
centenial anniversaries of the births of Holmes,
Poe and Lincoln are commemorated. All
countries, however, have combined in doing
homage to the memory of Charles Darwin.
Distinguished by impressive ceremonies and
eulogies from the lips of statesmen, poets and
scientists, dozens of meetings in his praise
have been held in every land, and in London,
Berlin, St. Petersburg, Paris and New York
statues of him have been unveiled. Seldom,
if ever, has a man of science received such
general recognition from the public, for
scientific heroes are not popular heroes, but
"Darwin's work was such that it affected
most human activity and all human thought."
This is indeed the truth, for all branches of
science, philosophy and religion have been
affected by evolution of Darwin's theory,
revolutionized the natural sciences. It is the
foundation of modern biological work; but it
also opened up new vistas to the other
sciences. Philosophy, especially psychology,
owes much of its recent progress to evolution.
The often talked of "war between science
and religion" is a direct outgrowth of Darwinism.
Darwin's theory is acknowledged by all
biologists, who now wonder not so much at
evolution as at its tardy discovery. "Evolution stares one in the face at every turn," but
the world is full of doubting Thomases, and
even today there are some who do not believe
that 'the Present is the child of the Past."
The theory of evolution is simple. It
denies the permanence of species, and says
there is "an answering change in all live
things to meet a previous change in nature."
In substance, Darwin said, "Grant me three
points, and I will prove evolution." In his
"Origin of species" he corroborated and
demonstrated these points. The first is the
law of heredity, the second is the law of
variation, the third is the struggle for existence in nature.
The law of heredity is known to everyone.
A cat never has a litter of puppies. The

young of bass are always bass. Hen's eggs
do not hatch out into ducklings. "No man
gathers figs from thistles." More than this,
two Persian cats will have Persian kittens;
black bass eggs do not hatch Oswego bass, the
chicks from a pen of Plymouth-rocks will
without exception be Plymouth-rocks, sweet
corn cannot be grown from field corn. Furthermore, cross-breds are a combination in
conformation, coloration, and instincts of
their parents, and, when fertile, will pass on
these combined qualities to their offspring.
This law of heredity is axiomatic, and it is
the foundation of• all animal breeding. The
skillful breeders of today mate stock that
conforms most nearly to their ideal, and in
time by always picking such specimens
(artifical selection) produce that ideal, or at
least as near to it as is probably possible.
The second law on which Darwin based his
theory of evolution is that of variability. We
all know that we have never seen two people
whom we could not distinguish. Even in the
striking resemblance between some twins
there are differences that are noticable to
those who know them well. This variation
also occurs in the lower animals and plants.
No one has much trouble in picking out the
members of a Fox-terrier family, but in a litter
of Scottish-terriers, where there is little difference in marking, most people are at sea. To
one with "an eye for live stock," , however,
they are quite as distinguishable as if they
were all labeled. Two friends were out at
the kennels with me one day trying to select
a puppy I had promised them. Neither knew
anything about dogs, but one could pick out
anyone of the twenty odd puppies which had
attracted her, while the other could not tell
one from the other. The kevelman, an old
Scotchman, took me aside and said, "The
wee lass ud mak' a rare joodge: she ken wha'
she want, but she dinna ken wha' to want."
This variation of external appearance is in all
living things and can be carried down to the
minutest details. No two elephants are alike,
nor are the left antennae of any two crickets
identical. This seems preposterous, but the
microscope shows it to be true.
Variation among animals and plants does
not, however, stop with external appearances.
No two skeltons of any species are identical.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

In one this bone is thicker, that one longer,
and such radical variation as difference in the
number of vertebra or phalanges is found in
man. Roughly, we all appreciate variation,
but few save the trained biologist realize how
widespread the action of the law is. It has
been suggested, in fact, that the root of variation lies in the mysterious protoplasm of each
minute living cell. Certain it is that the
blood, muscle tissue, borne, and even the seed
of different individuals of the same species yield
markedly different results under chemical
analysis.
There is still another kind of variation.
One Fox-hound, to use an example, is faster
than a second, but cannot trail as well as a
third, though he has a better 'tongue" than
either and has more endurance than all the
pack, but he is quite indifferent to petting.
Animals differ, as we do, in their dispositions,
the keenness of their senses, their ability to
withstand heat and cold, hunger and thirst,
their swiftness, and physical endurance. The
law of variation, therefore, is both physiological, and it affects all parts of all organisms,
but its action is not in any way uniform.
The third principle upon which Darwin
based his theory is the struggle for existence.
To one strolling through the woods or across
the meadows on a beautiful day `'when kindly
nature smiles on all," the idea of a fierce,
never-ending life and death fight in all creation seems impossible. And yet such a fight
is always going on, and thousands die for the
tens that live. Unless we think, we do not
notice it, for what has been called the balance
of nature has been established and swings
true. The number of individuals in a species
remains, under normal conditions, about constant. There are no great fluctuations, but a
terrible over-production of young is necessary
to maintain this ratio.
A few examples will make this clear. The
decendants from a single pair of hop amphids,
a small plant louse, would at the end of a
year when none died number ten thousand
million million. Placed one after another
these would make a line so long that light
traveling about 200,000 miles a second
would take two thousand nine hundred and
ninety years to pass from one end to the other.
Each season the robin lays from one to three

5

clutches of from three to six eggs. Taking
four as the average, which is surely a conservative estimate, at the end of ten years, if
the original pair and all their young lived,
there would be one hundred and eighteen
thousand and ninety-eight robins from the
first two. A common daisy, blooming as it
does for two months, will have about one
hundred and twenty-five blooms each of which
will have about five hundred seeds, making a
total of sixty-two thousand five hundred seeds
each season from each plant.
These figures show how many animals and
plants die to keep the balance of nature true.
The results when the balance is destroyed are
appaling. Everyone thought the rabbit a
harmless little creature when he was first imported into Australia, but now the Government there spends more money to keep down
the rabbits than for all other items. on its
budget. The mongoose was brought from
India to Jamaica to kill off the numerous
snakes, for he lives on snake eggs. He has
exterminated not only the snakes, but also
the birds, and is now a scourge. Any animal
out of its natut-al environment will either be
killed off or will break bounds, for he disturbs
the balance.
The practical application of these three
laws to evolution is by means of the survival
of the fittest, or natural selection, as Darwin
calls it. Let us take a hypothetical case.
The climate in a certain district is cooled
gradually, and a new phaze in the struggle
for existence faces the life of the region.
Those individuals which by variation are best
able to withstand cold live and by the law of
heredity their offspring inherit this quality,
passing it on indefinately as the weather keeps
on becoming more rigorous. Or again, a
certain bird preys on a certain insect, which
lives say on the underside of oak leaves.
Those of the insect which look even infinitesmally more like the lower side of oak leaves
stand just so much better chance of escaping
destruction. For ages this goes on till at last
an insect with highly specialized protective
coloration is developed. It is not hard to see,
with the complexity of enemies that each live
thing has and the great difference in conditions of life in different localities, that an
answering change in the organism to meet a

6

THE NEWS-LETTER.

previous change in nature might make species.
In this short sketch I have not found it
possible to do more than touch most lightly
on the fundamentals of Darwin's theory, nor
have I been able to take up such important
considerations as "use and disuse," "mutation," and hybid fertility. As for the proofs
of evolution—and there are many in bonmlogies and embryonic recapitulation—I have
been able to give none. I trust, however,
that I have been able to make clear that Darwin's theory of evolution is far more than
"the scientific dream of an atheistic mad
man," as a doctor of theology called "The
Origin of Species."
H., '12.

AN OUT-DOOR SCENE.
From a certain window in the Classical
Library one looks out upon Monument street,
and, "in particular," upon two red brick
buildings, the lighter in color being at the
top of the hill. It is not a cheerful view,
especially on a warm spring morning, with
the sun shining happily away, and the dreary
dust of old leather-bound copies of Aristotle
and other ancient heroes for the moment forgotten. The building that is lighter in color
is the Quaker Meeting House. But then it is
not Sunday, and there are no Quakeresses in
sight. With its tall, strangely built windows
the place looks too much like a factory building, and you turn away to the other 'temple,"
more fair to look upon. It is an enormous
affair, four stories high, with an hexagonal
turret on the right-hand side. This too is an
imposing building.
Its entrance reminds
you perhaps of that adamantine gate by
which the "Pius Aeneas" entered the lower
world.
You sigh with a feeling of sorrow for those
within, for you too once followed the rocky
road of old Archimede's paths. The sun
shines directly through a window-pane on the
head of a student listening to a lecture. The
student grows fidgety, and you smile, as you
remember the time when you too grew fidgety
for the same reason. Your eye wanders over
the huge, bulky, structure and lights finally
on the dome-shaped top of the hexagonal
turret. You idly wonder why it is painted
such a heathenish color. A tap on your

shoulder—a rancorous voice—"Mr. V. you
owe the Library twenty cents for overdue
books." You turn away and engage in the
business of the day.
V., '10.

LILLIAN GRAY.
It was the quiet twilight hour,
The busy world at rest;
A golden mist above the hills
That border on the west.
Adown the valley, robed in green,
Tripped lovely Lillian Gray.
And all the world was smiling then,
That sweet September day.
Well was she known through all the land
For countless kindly deeds.
She nursed the sick and fed the poor,
And tended to their needs.
Well was she known through all the land
For grace and beauty rare;
The lonely sufferer blessed her smile,
And knew her kind as fair.
She left behind the home of youth,
And sunny childhood days.
Forgotten all; for now is come
The parting of the ways.
And close beside her there that day
A smiling stranger stood.
Love waited for sweet Lillian Gray
At the edge of the wood.
T. S. W.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

THE HISTORY OF LACROSSE AT
JOHNS HOPKINS.
BY WILLIAM C.

SCHMhISSER.

November 10, 1908.

(Conlinued).
1899.
Next we come to the team of which "Toni
Fitz" was captain and "Ots" Glaser the
manager. The season's work was begun
early with little hope of great success, as
seven men of our crack '98 team had left the
University leaving as many vacancies to be
filled by new men. History tells us that
.there was a large number of candidates on
hand, but they were all green. Although
graduation had taken seven men from us, it
was yet kind in leaving us our big five. They
were: Maddren, McInnes, C. Guggenheimer,
Fitzgerald and R. T. Abercrombie. Also
upon close analysis we find that Guggenheimer played goal, in that year the greatest
goal-keeper in the United States; at cover
point we have "Billy" Maddren the old war
horse and coach of the team. Then we skip
three places only to meet Abercrombie at
centre, who got to be known in the. Lacrosse
world as the "Hopkins Centre" playing this
position for five successive years. Next to
him we locate Tom Fitzgerald at third attack
whom we can best describe with these seven
words: tall, speedy, nervy, heady and a
dodger. On account of this last characteristic the writer has never seen Fitzgerald come

7

out of a lacrosse game without a good assortment of court plaster all over his face. He
was when necessary, a fine individual player.
Again we skip three places only to shake
hands with our great and only "Cannuck."
"Mac"—he in mind of those who ought to
know—is considered up-to-date the greatest
in home Hopkins has ever had. We have had
quicker shots but for the all around man who
has endurance, speed when necessary, stickwork, dodging ability and head-work, McInnes stands alone. Such men were the five
lone men that graduation left us and just in
those positions where they were of most value
to the team. It was this combination of old
men that gave the team a balance. The new
men filled in the other places being sandwitched in between the old stock. Of these
Robert H. Grimes at first attack was the surprise of the season, his goal shooting was
good.
After months of faithful training by Maddren, the team started its season by beating
Columbia in New York City by a score of 8
to I. The game showed up nothing of particular interest except that Columbia also
knew that McInnes was a dangerous attack
man. They did not know him by sight but
by reputation and started in to cover up our
out home Preston, (who played the first and
only game in his life that day) believing him
to be "Mac." This mistake on their part was
brought about by the usual foresight of our
coach who had suggested that "Mac" and

8

THE NEWS-LETTER.

Preston change names for the occasion.
Next Harvard was played to a standstill to
the tune of 20 to 0. The game was uninteresting as can be readily inferred from the
score.
The real test of the season came when the
"Black and Blue" lined up against the Crescent Athletic Club of Brooklyn at Electric
Park. This was the first time that your historian was introduced to these brilliant players, and to confess the truth thought they
were entirely too stout and old to do any fast
work and deducted the illogical result that
they would be "easy meat" for our boys.
The game began and it might be mentioned
in passing that Billy Hodges, one of our '98
team men, did most of the mid field running
for Crescents that day. After a very hotly
contested game, and good work all around,
especially by Guggenheimer, the game ended
in favor of the New Yorkers by a score of
5 to 2.
When it came to the Championship Games,
Stevens was beaten by the score of 12 to 5, yet
it was a hard fought game between two strong
attacks as can be seen by the fact that five
goals were scored on our goal man.
A week later the team started for Lehigh,
it would be more accurate to say part of it,
because when the train pulled out of the
station Bandel, our dear "Jay," was found
wanting. Suffice it to say that the lost freshman arrived in South Bethlehem in time to
don his lacrosse costume and go in the game.
For a detailed account of the side issues of
this trip I respectfully refer to the Hullabaloo
of 1900 which says: -Everything depended
on this game; and twenty-four hours before
the battle nervousness was a characteristic not
only of the players, but of the little party of
rooters who accompanied the team to South
Bethlehem. This nervousness took at times
a curious shape. The "Colonel"(Crenshaw)
recounted time and again the remarkable
story of "Billy White," and Campbell bought
one peck of oranges at the early hour of 1 A.
M., with apparently no other purpose than to
throw them through windows. Amid the
crash of falling glass, the 'Colonel" started off
once more: "Well, let me tell you. Two or
three Lehigh men and Billy—." but Campbell jammed his last orange down the "Colo-

nel's" throat and he choked on the word
''White.'
"Two or three of our more curious members tried to discover the workings of the fire
escape, and whether it was effective in lowering bed-room china as human carcasses. It
proved to be quite as efficient, only the crockery broke. However, that was the manager's
business. Few were the hours of sleep that
night, and on the morrow the great battle!"
'`During the first few minutes of the game'
says the Hullabaloo, "uncertainty prevailed,
but soon the fellows warmed to, and the rest,
well, in little more than an hour we were
again champions." Score, 11 to 3.

1900.
Two successive lacrosse championships had
given Hopkins a firm hold on the Baltimore
public and made her a great factor in the
lacrosse world, but after the season of 1900
closed and R. T. Abercrombie with his team
carried off the third victory, the satisfaction of
the student body was supreme and it honored
the different members of the team with a
little token of their esteem in the shape of a
lacrosse medal.
As in many a previous year the season
opened gloomily for we had lost such men as
Fitzgerald, "Guggy," and Harry Grimes.
But once again Hopkins lacrosse luck, splendid coaching by the "old war horse" and
good handling landed our team winner by a
close margin. How close can only be appreciated by those who played in the Stevens

had a chance. The chance came often,
Symington would go out and get the ball and
try to dodge Straus who with peculiar regularity caught him amidships and then
smilingly waited while Lehigh's first attack
lay on turf recuperating.
On the whole, the game was a hard fought
one and everyone on the team having their
hands full, responded nobly. The final score
was 5 to 0 in favor of the "Black and the
Blue."
Well! the game with Stevens, the famous
game at Stevens, when after crippling most
of our men by throwing them over benches
and other minor obstacles which the umpire
refused to remove, the audience saluted our
men with the cry "Kill them!" was the next
on the schedule.
But so that history may be complete we must
first turn back to the railroad station in Baltimore and watch Manager Lindham dressed in
his new Ragland with its continuous inside
pockets, as he passed the team through the
gates. Soon all are passed and as the despatcher calls "All abroad" Rudolph pushes
the tickets into one of his pockets and enters
the train. All goes well until the conductor
demands of our manager the self same tickets.
They cannot be found so after a fruitless
search, of half an hour, our manager telegraphs to Baltimore from the next station
asking the gate-keeper whether any tickets
had been found.
Just as Lindheim had settled down in his
seat, finding fault with his new coat for
having false pockets, in walks Bert Bernheim,
the Hopkins out home, a much travelled man
from Kentucky and always ready for a bet
with a good thirst attached. What's the
matter ``Lindy" comes the query? Next we
hear a five minutes' laugh from "Berny" and
then the following: "I'll bet you a bottle of
champagne that those tickets are in your
pocket." The manager: "I'll take you up."
Then everybody crowds around as Bernheim
begins his hunt for that bottle. One pocket:
no result; pocket number two: a dig behind
the label—the tickets, and "Bert" wins amid
the shouts of the crowd assembled.
Now as to the game with Stevens: We
started in with a rush, but Stevens drew first
blood by scoring almost immediately. Then

our boys steadied down, however, and before
very long the Bandel Brothers, especially
Bernard who was in good trim that !day, shot
a few goals, while McInnes walked up and
down the crease and mixed it up with his old
friend Layat, Stevens goal tend. By the
time the second half was reached our light
attack on account of very rough playing, was
pretty well used up. "Jay" Bandel was all
in and the burden of the midfield work fell on
Norton and Abercrombie. Luck also seemed
to be against us and "Al" Bruton sprained
his ankle but kept on in the game. To cap
the climax, Maddren was put out of the game
for five minutes for rough playing and our
boys were forced to keep on with ten men as
Bruton could not be depended on. The
minute our coach was put out, Stevens
started in with a terrific rush while Captain
Abercrombie called "Mac" back to play cover
point. Now the score stood four to three in
favor of Hopkins and it was only bad generalship on the part of our opponents that saved
the game for us at this same score. For when
McInnes was removed from in home to cover
point, Stevens kept both their point and cover

When Maddren got back into the game it
was only a short time before the whistle blew

After the game was over ''Mac" McInnis
was ready to fight everybody in sight who
looked like a Stevens man; and even that
evening when the team and Hopkins rooters
were gathered together in one of the bed
rooms of the Astor Hotel, talking about the
game, the former bathing their bruises in
Lindheim's bottle of champagne,while 'Mac"
was fast asleep on the bed worn out after his
tussle with Layat, we were suddenly startled
by hearing him say ''Get out you pig-headed
fool."

My Ma believes in women's rights;
She's called a suffragette.
She gets a lot of ladies 'round,
And argues some, you bet.
She knows a lot 'bout law and things;
Says, '`Woman must be freed!''
But just as soon as evening comes,
She ambles home to feed.
Now Pa ain't much on clubs and such,
He don't do much but grind,
And pays Bill's bills. When Ma goes out,
He's always left behind.
He stays down-town the whole day long
To work for things we need.
But just as soon as evening comes,
He ambles home to feed.

My sister Annie takes her beau
And strolls down Charles street.
They stop in Guth's with all the rest,
To get some stuff to eat.
Or, maybe, its a shopping trip
For something she don't need;
But just as soon as evening comes,
She ambles home to feed.
Brother Bill plays football now,
And goes to Hopkins too.
He spends pa's cash on wine and song
And fusses some 'tis true.
He seems to be a busy man,
He spends a lot, indeed;
But just as soon as evening comes,
He ambles home to feed.

114—V HE Editor of this sheet is frequently soluted by such remarks as
*****
I• MMO. •
''Never was so stung in my life as when I paid $1.50 for your paper,"
or 'Is the NEWS-LETTER as rotten as usual this week?" or some
equally complimentary speech. Now we know this paper is almost as
•
•
bad as you say. And you who have paid your plunk and a half may
*
visit Pluto, for all we care; but for the benefit of possible future subscribers we would like to say that we try, and sincerely try, to make
*********41*
this paper worth your while. Not long ago, for instance, we offered
;4 Mit
*Ak
a cash prize for the best design ,for a cover. We received one draw**
ing—and of that the less said the better. We have time and again
entreated the youthful Raphael and Shakspere who likes to see his work in print to submit it
to us. And still we find it necessary to hunt for subjects on which to write to fill up our bimonthly issues. Six ordinary men, as we editors undoubtedly are, cannot be expected to give
you a Harper's for your $1.50.
Now, if you have an idea, let us have it; if some secret grief against the University is
gnawing at your hearts strings, let us have it; if the return of spring has stirred up the poetry
of your soul, give it to us. Write to us, kick all you want, only, don't ''cuss out" the faculty,
and if ifs better than we can do ourselves we'll publish it.
Now let's see what happens.

We print in this issue an article on Darwinism, by our Mr. Haynes. Such an article is

The Class of 1910 has finally succeeded in getting together, and organizing. We
always felt rather sorrow for that class, whose members never knew whether they were juniors
or sophomores. Now, however, we are inclined to envy them. A glance at the ticket elected
shows that every man got an office. Were we but a member, honor might have been heaped
upon us as well.
Looking over the ticket we cannot fail to be impressed with the literary value of the
class. A poet is president, two other poets serve beneath him, and an orator sits at his right
hand. Look to your laurels, oh ye of 1909.

The doors leading from McCoy Hall to Monument street and Druid Hill avenue open
inwards. The law requires doors from all public halls to open outwards. This rule, we
understand, is technically obeyed by having the doors from the Assembly Hall into the
corridor open outwards. This is no matter for technicalities! There is surely danger in the
present system, even though that danger be small.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

DARWIN'S THEORY.
The year 1809 saw the birth of many great
men, and we in 1909 .have been celebrating
many important centenaries. England honors
Fitzgerald, Gladstone and Tennyson; Germany, Mendelssohn, and in this country the
centenial anniversaries of the births of Holmes,
Poe and Lincoln are commemorated. All
countries, however, have combined in doing
homage to the memory of Charles Darwin.
Distinguished by impressive ceremonies and
eulogies from the lips of statesmen, poets and
scientists, dozens of meetings in his praise
have been held in every land, and in London,
Berlin, St. Petersburg, Paris and New York
statues of him have been unveiled. Seldom,
if ever, has a man of science received such
general recognition from the public, for
scientific heroes are not popular heroes, but
"Darwin's work was such that it affected
most human activity and all human thought."
This is indeed the truth, for all branches of
science, philosophy and religion have been
affected by evolution of Darwin's theory,
revolutionized the natural sciences. It is the
foundation of modern biological work; but it
also opened up new vistas to the other
sciences. Philosophy, especially psychology,
owes much of its recent progress to evolution.
The often talked of "war between science
and religion" is a direct outgrowth of Darwinism.
Darwin's theory is acknowledged by all
biologists, who now wonder not so much at
evolution as at its tardy discovery. "Evolution stares one in the face at every turn," but
the world is full of doubting Thomases, and
even today there are some who do not believe
that 'the Present is the child of the Past."
The theory of evolution is simple. It
denies the permanence of species, and says
there is "an answering change in all live
things to meet a previous change in nature."
In substance, Darwin said, "Grant me three
points, and I will prove evolution." In his
"Origin of species" he corroborated and
demonstrated these points. The first is the
law of heredity, the second is the law of
variation, the third is the struggle for existence in nature.
The law of heredity is known to everyone.
A cat never has a litter of puppies. The

young of bass are always bass. Hen's eggs
do not hatch out into ducklings. "No man
gathers figs from thistles." More than this,
two Persian cats will have Persian kittens;
black bass eggs do not hatch Oswego bass, the
chicks from a pen of Plymouth-rocks will
without exception be Plymouth-rocks, sweet
corn cannot be grown from field corn. Furthermore, cross-breds are a combination in
conformation, coloration, and instincts of
their parents, and, when fertile, will pass on
these combined qualities to their offspring.
This law of heredity is axiomatic, and it is
the foundation of• all animal breeding. The
skillful breeders of today mate stock that
conforms most nearly to their ideal, and in
time by always picking such specimens
(artifical selection) produce that ideal, or at
least as near to it as is probably possible.
The second law on which Darwin based his
theory of evolution is that of variability. We
all know that we have never seen two people
whom we could not distinguish. Even in the
striking resemblance between some twins
there are differences that are noticable to
those who know them well. This variation
also occurs in the lower animals and plants.
No one has much trouble in picking out the
members of a Fox-terrier family, but in a litter
of Scottish-terriers, where there is little difference in marking, most people are at sea. To
one with "an eye for live stock," , however,
they are quite as distinguishable as if they
were all labeled. Two friends were out at
the kennels with me one day trying to select
a puppy I had promised them. Neither knew
anything about dogs, but one could pick out
anyone of the twenty odd puppies which had
attracted her, while the other could not tell
one from the other. The kevelman, an old
Scotchman, took me aside and said, "The
wee lass ud mak' a rare joodge: she ken wha'
she want, but she dinna ken wha' to want."
This variation of external appearance is in all
living things and can be carried down to the
minutest details. No two elephants are alike,
nor are the left antennae of any two crickets
identical. This seems preposterous, but the
microscope shows it to be true.
Variation among animals and plants does
not, however, stop with external appearances.
No two skeltons of any species are identical.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

In one this bone is thicker, that one longer,
and such radical variation as difference in the
number of vertebra or phalanges is found in
man. Roughly, we all appreciate variation,
but few save the trained biologist realize how
widespread the action of the law is. It has
been suggested, in fact, that the root of variation lies in the mysterious protoplasm of each
minute living cell. Certain it is that the
blood, muscle tissue, borne, and even the seed
of different individuals of the same species yield
markedly different results under chemical
analysis.
There is still another kind of variation.
One Fox-hound, to use an example, is faster
than a second, but cannot trail as well as a
third, though he has a better 'tongue" than
either and has more endurance than all the
pack, but he is quite indifferent to petting.
Animals differ, as we do, in their dispositions,
the keenness of their senses, their ability to
withstand heat and cold, hunger and thirst,
their swiftness, and physical endurance. The
law of variation, therefore, is both physiological, and it affects all parts of all organisms,
but its action is not in any way uniform.
The third principle upon which Darwin
based his theory is the struggle for existence.
To one strolling through the woods or across
the meadows on a beautiful day `'when kindly
nature smiles on all," the idea of a fierce,
never-ending life and death fight in all creation seems impossible. And yet such a fight
is always going on, and thousands die for the
tens that live. Unless we think, we do not
notice it, for what has been called the balance
of nature has been established and swings
true. The number of individuals in a species
remains, under normal conditions, about constant. There are no great fluctuations, but a
terrible over-production of young is necessary
to maintain this ratio.
A few examples will make this clear. The
decendants from a single pair of hop amphids,
a small plant louse, would at the end of a
year when none died number ten thousand
million million. Placed one after another
these would make a line so long that light
traveling about 200,000 miles a second
would take two thousand nine hundred and
ninety years to pass from one end to the other.
Each season the robin lays from one to three

5

clutches of from three to six eggs. Taking
four as the average, which is surely a conservative estimate, at the end of ten years, if
the original pair and all their young lived,
there would be one hundred and eighteen
thousand and ninety-eight robins from the
first two. A common daisy, blooming as it
does for two months, will have about one
hundred and twenty-five blooms each of which
will have about five hundred seeds, making a
total of sixty-two thousand five hundred seeds
each season from each plant.
These figures show how many animals and
plants die to keep the balance of nature true.
The results when the balance is destroyed are
appaling. Everyone thought the rabbit a
harmless little creature when he was first imported into Australia, but now the Government there spends more money to keep down
the rabbits than for all other items. on its
budget. The mongoose was brought from
India to Jamaica to kill off the numerous
snakes, for he lives on snake eggs. He has
exterminated not only the snakes, but also
the birds, and is now a scourge. Any animal
out of its natut-al environment will either be
killed off or will break bounds, for he disturbs
the balance.
The practical application of these three
laws to evolution is by means of the survival
of the fittest, or natural selection, as Darwin
calls it. Let us take a hypothetical case.
The climate in a certain district is cooled
gradually, and a new phaze in the struggle
for existence faces the life of the region.
Those individuals which by variation are best
able to withstand cold live and by the law of
heredity their offspring inherit this quality,
passing it on indefinately as the weather keeps
on becoming more rigorous. Or again, a
certain bird preys on a certain insect, which
lives say on the underside of oak leaves.
Those of the insect which look even infinitesmally more like the lower side of oak leaves
stand just so much better chance of escaping
destruction. For ages this goes on till at last
an insect with highly specialized protective
coloration is developed. It is not hard to see,
with the complexity of enemies that each live
thing has and the great difference in conditions of life in different localities, that an
answering change in the organism to meet a

6

THE NEWS-LETTER.

previous change in nature might make species.
In this short sketch I have not found it
possible to do more than touch most lightly
on the fundamentals of Darwin's theory, nor
have I been able to take up such important
considerations as "use and disuse," "mutation," and hybid fertility. As for the proofs
of evolution—and there are many in bonmlogies and embryonic recapitulation—I have
been able to give none. I trust, however,
that I have been able to make clear that Darwin's theory of evolution is far more than
"the scientific dream of an atheistic mad
man," as a doctor of theology called "The
Origin of Species."
H., '12.

AN OUT-DOOR SCENE.
From a certain window in the Classical
Library one looks out upon Monument street,
and, "in particular," upon two red brick
buildings, the lighter in color being at the
top of the hill. It is not a cheerful view,
especially on a warm spring morning, with
the sun shining happily away, and the dreary
dust of old leather-bound copies of Aristotle
and other ancient heroes for the moment forgotten. The building that is lighter in color
is the Quaker Meeting House. But then it is
not Sunday, and there are no Quakeresses in
sight. With its tall, strangely built windows
the place looks too much like a factory building, and you turn away to the other 'temple,"
more fair to look upon. It is an enormous
affair, four stories high, with an hexagonal
turret on the right-hand side. This too is an
imposing building.
Its entrance reminds
you perhaps of that adamantine gate by
which the "Pius Aeneas" entered the lower
world.
You sigh with a feeling of sorrow for those
within, for you too once followed the rocky
road of old Archimede's paths. The sun
shines directly through a window-pane on the
head of a student listening to a lecture. The
student grows fidgety, and you smile, as you
remember the time when you too grew fidgety
for the same reason. Your eye wanders over
the huge, bulky, structure and lights finally
on the dome-shaped top of the hexagonal
turret. You idly wonder why it is painted
such a heathenish color. A tap on your

shoulder—a rancorous voice—"Mr. V. you
owe the Library twenty cents for overdue
books." You turn away and engage in the
business of the day.
V., '10.

LILLIAN GRAY.
It was the quiet twilight hour,
The busy world at rest;
A golden mist above the hills
That border on the west.
Adown the valley, robed in green,
Tripped lovely Lillian Gray.
And all the world was smiling then,
That sweet September day.
Well was she known through all the land
For countless kindly deeds.
She nursed the sick and fed the poor,
And tended to their needs.
Well was she known through all the land
For grace and beauty rare;
The lonely sufferer blessed her smile,
And knew her kind as fair.
She left behind the home of youth,
And sunny childhood days.
Forgotten all; for now is come
The parting of the ways.
And close beside her there that day
A smiling stranger stood.
Love waited for sweet Lillian Gray
At the edge of the wood.
T. S. W.

SCHMhISSER.

November 10, 1908.

1899.
Next we come to the team of which "Toni
Fitz" was captain and "Ots" Glaser the
manager. The season's work was begun
early with little hope of great success, as
seven men of our crack '98 team had left the
University leaving as many vacancies to be
filled by new men. History tells us that
.there was a large number of candidates on
hand, but they were all green. Although
graduation had taken seven men from us, it
was yet kind in leaving us our big five. They
were: Maddren, McInnes, C. Guggenheimer,
Fitzgerald and R. T. Abercrombie. Also
upon close analysis we find that Guggenheimer played goal, in that year the greatest
goal-keeper in the United States; at cover
point we have "Billy" Maddren the old war
horse and coach of the team. Then we skip
three places only to meet Abercrombie at
centre, who got to be known in the. Lacrosse
world as the "Hopkins Centre" playing this
position for five successive years. Next to
him we locate Tom Fitzgerald at third attack
whom we can best describe with these seven
words: tall, speedy, nervy, heady and a
dodger. On account of this last characteristic the writer has never seen Fitzgerald come

7

out of a lacrosse game without a good assortment of court plaster all over his face. He
was when necessary, a fine individual player.
Again we skip three places only to shake
hands with our great and only "Cannuck."
"Mac"—he in mind of those who ought to
know—is considered up-to-date the greatest
in home Hopkins has ever had. We have had
quicker shots but for the all around man who
has endurance, speed when necessary, stickwork, dodging ability and head-work, McInnes stands alone. Such men were the five
lone men that graduation left us and just in
those positions where they were of most value
to the team. It was this combination of old
men that gave the team a balance. The new
men filled in the other places being sandwitched in between the old stock. Of these
Robert H. Grimes at first attack was the surprise of the season, his goal shooting was
good.
After months of faithful training by Maddren, the team started its season by beating
Columbia in New York City by a score of 8
to I. The game showed up nothing of particular interest except that Columbia also
knew that McInnes was a dangerous attack
man. They did not know him by sight but
by reputation and started in to cover up our
out home Preston, (who played the first and
only game in his life that day) believing him
to be "Mac." This mistake on their part was
brought about by the usual foresight of our
coach who had suggested that "Mac" and

Preston change names for the occasion.
Next Harvard was played to a standstill to
the tune of 20 to 0. The game was uninteresting as can be readily inferred from the
score.
The real test of the season came when the
"Black and Blue" lined up against the Crescent Athletic Club of Brooklyn at Electric
Park. This was the first time that your historian was introduced to these brilliant players, and to confess the truth thought they
were entirely too stout and old to do any fast
work and deducted the illogical result that
they would be "easy meat" for our boys.
The game began and it might be mentioned
in passing that Billy Hodges, one of our '98
team men, did most of the mid field running
for Crescents that day. After a very hotly
contested game, and good work all around,
especially by Guggenheimer, the game ended
in favor of the New Yorkers by a score of
5 to 2.
When it came to the Championship Games,
Stevens was beaten by the score of 12 to 5, yet
it was a hard fought game between two strong
attacks as can be seen by the fact that five
goals were scored on our goal man.
A week later the team started for Lehigh,
it would be more accurate to say part of it,
because when the train pulled out of the
station Bandel, our dear "Jay," was found
wanting. Suffice it to say that the lost freshman arrived in South Bethlehem in time to
don his lacrosse costume and go in the game.
For a detailed account of the side issues of
this trip I respectfully refer to the Hullabaloo
of 1900 which says: -Everything depended
on this game; and twenty-four hours before
the battle nervousness was a characteristic not
only of the players, but of the little party of
rooters who accompanied the team to South
Bethlehem. This nervousness took at times
a curious shape. The "Colonel"(Crenshaw)
recounted time and again the remarkable
story of "Billy White," and Campbell bought
one peck of oranges at the early hour of 1 A.
M., with apparently no other purpose than to
throw them through windows. Amid the
crash of falling glass, the 'Colonel" started off
once more: "Well, let me tell you. Two or
three Lehigh men and Billy—." but Campbell jammed his last orange down the "Colo-

nel's" throat and he choked on the word
''White.'
"Two or three of our more curious members tried to discover the workings of the fire
escape, and whether it was effective in lowering bed-room china as human carcasses. It
proved to be quite as efficient, only the crockery broke. However, that was the manager's
business. Few were the hours of sleep that
night, and on the morrow the great battle!"
'`During the first few minutes of the game'
says the Hullabaloo, "uncertainty prevailed,
but soon the fellows warmed to, and the rest,
well, in little more than an hour we were
again champions." Score, 11 to 3.

1900.
Two successive lacrosse championships had
given Hopkins a firm hold on the Baltimore

little token of their esteem in the shape of a
lacrosse medal.
As in many a previous year the season
opened gloomily for we had lost such men as
Fitzgerald, "Guggy," and Harry Grimes.
But once again Hopkins lacrosse luck, splendid coaching by the "old war horse" and
good handling landed our team winner by a

Just as Lindheim had settled down in his

They had to score to win.
When Maddren got back into the game it
was only a short time before the whistle blew
and Hopkins boys were for the first time,
three-time champions.
After the game was over ''Mac" McInnis
was ready to fight everybody in sight who
looked like a Stevens man; and even that
evening when the team and Hopkins rooters
were gathered together in one of the bed
rooms of the Astor Hotel, talking about the
game, the former bathing their bruises in
Lindheim's bottle of champagne,while 'Mac"
was fast asleep on the bed worn out after his
tussle with Layat, we were suddenly startled
by hearing him say ''Get out you pig-headed
fool."
So closed that season successfully fought by
the team which lined up as follows:
Frederick Harry Baetjer, goal; William C.
Schmeisser, point; William Harry Maddren,
cover point; Henry Philip Straus, first defense;
Alfred William Bruton, second defense; Frederick Foster, third defense; Ronald T. Abercrombie, centre; Eugene Levering Norton,
third attack; James Edward Tyler, Bernard
B. Bandel, second attack; John Martin Bandel, first attack; Bertram M. Bernheim, out
home; Charles R. McInnis, in home; Ronald
T. Abercrombie, captain; Norvin Rudolph
Lindheim, manager.

My Ma believes in women's rights;
She's called a suffragette.
She gets a lot of ladies 'round,
And argues some, you bet.
She knows a lot 'bout law and things;
Says, '`Woman must be freed!''
But just as soon as evening comes,
She ambles home to feed.
Now Pa ain't much on clubs and such,
He don't do much but grind,
And pays Bill's bills. When Ma goes out,
He's always left behind.
He stays down-town the whole day long
To work for things we need.
But just as soon as evening comes,
He ambles home to feed.

My sister Annie takes her beau
And strolls down Charles street.
They stop in Guth's with all the rest,
To get some stuff to eat.
Or, maybe, its a shopping trip
For something she don't need;
But just as soon as evening comes,
She ambles home to feed.
Brother Bill plays football now,
And goes to Hopkins too.
He spends pa's cash on wine and song
And fusses some 'tis true.
He seems to be a busy man,
He spends a lot, indeed;
But just as soon as evening comes,
He ambles home to feed.
